form.current-chamber: IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES

action.action-desc: Ms. Klobuchar (for herself and Mr. Hoeven) introduced the following bill; which was read twice and referred to the Committee on Commerce, Science, and Transportation

form.official-title: To amend title 23, United States Code, to improve highway safety and for other purposes.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Improving Driver Safety Act of 2014.
Section 405(e) of title 23, United States Code, is amended—

paragraph.text: in paragraph (1), by inserting includes distracted driving issues as part of the State’s driver’s license examination and after any State that;

subparagraph.text: in subparagraph (B), by inserting and at the end;

paragraph.text: in paragraph (4)(C), by striking section 31152 and inserting section 31136; and
by amending paragraph (6) to read as follows:

subparagraph.text: The Secretary may use up to 50 percent of the amounts available for grants under this subsection to award grants to any State that—

subclause.text: has a basic text messaging statute, as determined by the Secretary, that—

item.text: is applicable to drivers of all ages; and
makes violation of the basic text messaging statute a primary offense;

subclause.text: participates in the annual distracted driving law enforcement mobilization coordinated by the Secretary; and
is otherwise ineligible for a grant under this subsection;
imposes increased fines for repeat violations; and
has a statute that prohibits a driver who is younger than 18 years of age from using a personal wireless communications device while driving.

clause.text: Subject to clauses (ii) and (iii), amounts received by a State under subparagraph (A) may be used for activities related to the enforcement of distracted driving laws.
In fiscal year 2015, up to 15 percent of the amounts received by a State under subparagraph (A) may be used for any eligible project or activity under section 402.
In fiscal year 2016, up to 25 percent of the amounts received by a State under subparagraph (A) may be used for any eligible project or activity under section 402.

section.text: Not later than 180 days after the date of the enactment of this Act, the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration shall submit a report to the Committee on Commerce, Science, and Transportation of the Senate, the Committee on Energy and Commerce of the House of Representatives, and the Committee on Transportation and Infrastructure of the House of Representatives that—

paragraph.text: identifies any legal and technical barriers to capturing adequate data on the prevalence of wireless communications devices while driving; and
provides recommendations on how to address such barriers.
